author: tlsalex
body:
Within a shell (Powershell) , how to show all info that show in GUI task manager.  any cmdlet do that job ?

GUI:
![task_manager](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36788337/56625008-cd19cf80-666d-11e9-9079-871376a90ed6.png)

Expect PowerShell Version Work Like This
![top](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36788337/56625074-1407c500-666e-11e9-8347-c33017df2950.png)

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body: PowerShell's `Get-Process` (`gps`) displays a lot of this information. The .NET Process object has access to almost all of it, so if you want a different view you could write a formatter. Otherwise, on *nix platforms, `top` and `htop` are also excellent tools.

comments.author: tlsalex
comments.body: Hello @rjmholt , thanks ,  but within gps , can not see the overall resource usage , like cpu, memory  and disk overall usage. it just shows the resource usage for single process.

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body: Your best option is likely to [create a new formatter](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_format.ps1xml?view=powershell-6). You could then add [PowerShell calls to get total system resource usage](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6298941/how-do-i-find-the-cpu-and-ram-usage-using-powershell) and put them at the top.

comments.author: fMichaleczek
comments.body:
if you want to explore the same data as TaskManager, PowerShell can help you to automate things. 

If you want a fast C++ window top, check on github this project : [NTop](https://github.com/Nuke928/NTop).  This kind of tools takes all the console, so powershell or not, there is no difference at all. (except if the tool only works on cmd and has weird display in PS).

comments.author: tlsalex
comments.body:
Hello @fmichaleczek ,
NTop it does a very cool tool , however it still missing something that I want , which is the disk usage for each process , I already raise a request for that feature under NTop project.

I am more prefer the official powershell-like NTop.

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body: Closing this issue since it's out of scope for the PowerShell project. A feature like this would work better as its own module, since it would then work with older PowerShell versions too.

title: new request : powershell equivalent of task manager
